1.brief: to judge, i.e. pronounce sentence (for or against); by implication, to vindicate or punish; by extenssion, to govern; passively, to litigate (literally or figuratively)

gods in the ordinary sense; but specifically used (in the plural thus, especially with the article) of the supreme God; occasionally applied by way of deference to magistrates; and sometimes as a superlative
properly, to toss, i.e. grapple; mostly figuratively, to wrangle, i.e. hold a controversy; (by implication) to defend
a foreign nation; hence, a Gentile; also (figuratively) a troop of animals, or a flight of locusts
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
a man as an individual or a male person; often used as an adjunct to a more definite term (and in such cases frequently not expressed in translation)
to slip out, i.e. escape; causatively, to deliver

2.brief: (by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
thou and thee, or (plural) ye and you

gods in the ordinary sense; but specifically used (in the plural thus, especially with the article) of the supreme God; occasionally applied by way of deference to magistrates; and sometimes as a superlative
a fortified place; figuratively, a defence

properly, interrogative what? (including how? why? when?); but also exclamation, what! (including how!), or indefinitely what (including whatever, and even relatively, that which); often used with prefixes in various adverbial or conjunctive senses

properly, interrogative what? (including how? why? when?); but also exclamation, what! (including how!), or indefinitely what (including whatever, and even relatively, that which); often used with prefixes in various adverbial or conjunctive senses
to be ashy, i.e. darkcolored; by implication, to mourn (in sackcloth or sordid garments)
to walk (in a great variety of applications, literally and figuratively)

3.brief: to send away, for, or out (in a great variety of applications)
illumination or (concrete) luminary (in every sense, including lightning, happiness, etc.)
to guide; by implication, to transport (into exile, or as colonists)
to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)
near, with or among; often in general, to
a mountain or range of hills (sometimes used figuratively)
a sacred place or thing; rarely abstract, sanctity
near, with or among; often in general, to
a residence (including a shepherd's hut, the lair of animals, figuratively, the grave; also the Temple); specifically, the Tabernacle (properly, its wooden walls)

4.brief: to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)
near, with or among; often in general, to

gods in the ordinary sense; but specifically used (in the plural thus, especially with the article) of the supreme God; occasionally applied by way of deference to magistrates; and sometimes as a superlative
near, with or among; often in general, to
strength; as adjective, mighty; especially the Almighty (but used also of any deity)
a revolution (of time, i.e. an age); also joy
physically, to throw (a stone, an arrow) at or away; especially to revere or worship (with extended hands); intensively, to bemoan (by wringing the hands)

gods in the ordinary sense; but specifically used (in the plural thus, especially with the article) of the supreme God; occasionally applied by way of deference to magistrates; and sometimes as a superlative

to sink or depress (reflexive or causative)
properly, a breathing creature, i.e. animal of (abstractly) vitality; used very widely in a literal, accommodated or figurative sense (bodily or mental)

properly, interrogative what? (including how? why? when?); but also exclamation, what! (including how!), or indefinitely what (including whatever, and even relatively, that which); often used with prefixes in various adverbial or conjunctive senses
to make a loud sound (like English 'hum'); by implication, to be in great commotion or tumult, to rage, war, moan, clamor
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
to wait; by implication, to be patient, hope

gods in the ordinary sense; but specifically used (in the plural thus, especially with the article) of the supreme God; occasionally applied by way of deference to magistrates; and sometimes as a superlative

properly, iteration or continuance; used only adverbially (with or without preposition), again, repeatedly, still, more

something saved, i.e. (abstractly) deliverance; hence, aid, victory, prosperity
the face (as the part that turns); used in a great variety of applications (literally and figuratively); also (with prepositional prefix) as a preposition (before, etc.)
